   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 81 yo f with HTN, HL, CHF, ESRD on HD, malnutrition, here
   with recurrent respiratory distress secondary to RLL lobar collapse
   (?TBM vs aspiration with mucous plugging vs HAP) now extubated.
   .
   #.  Respiratory failure:
   Patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress.
   Reportedly has TBM but left sided lesion is too distal to stent. Has
   positive glucan/galactomannan, and CT on [**4-14**] showing diffuse disease,
   possibly invasive aspergilliosis. Was started on oral voriconazole on
   [**2190-4-15**], but with elevated LFT
s to thousands; vori is discontinued.
   Due to multiple respiratory problems, patient may ultimately require
   another intubation which she has stated she would want.  Will continue
   to remove fluid as possible with dialysis. Must also consider that some
   component of resp failure could be PE from known RUE DVT, though did
   not tolerate anticoagulation.  Tenuous respiratory status overall today
   and is visibly tired and tachypnic.  Now off steroids. CT sinus showing
   fluid in mastoids not concerning for invasive fungal disease there.
   - completed course for HAP with Vancomycin (D1 [**4-10**]) & cefepime (D1
   [**4-9**]), both d/c on [**4-17**]
   - discontinued Voriconazole (D1 was [**4-16**]) due to LFT elevation
   - cont liposomal ampho (D1 was [**4-20**])
   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - PT
   - failed speech and swallow eval.
   - consider non-invasive ventilation
   - resend ABG
   - consider repeat CT, though patient would not be able to tolerate the
   study at this time.
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol today before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - consider midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. HTN/Hypotension.  On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on
   captopril and amlodipine here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **]
   beta-blocker given concurrent rhythm issues.  In ICU has had very
   labile hypertensive blood pressure but is hypotensive today
   - will control on metoprolol on non-HD days as per above
   - restart neo to maintain perfusion
   - replace a-line
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #. Liver:
   Patient has had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Med effect vs.
   hypotensive/shock liver. Vori is discontinued, currently on liposomal
   amphoterocin. Will support pressures to keep SBP above 100.  Downward
   trending LFT
s since period of hypotension.
   - Hepatology signed off.  LFT
s improving, likely related to ischemic
   liver
   - liver US with dopplers
 Normal right lobe of the liver, limited view
   of the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - ammonia nml
   - cont to trend LFT
   # AMS:
   Given timing with liver damage, likely related. [**Month (only) 51**] be encephalopathy
   vs. hypotension/hypoxia. CT scan negative.  Plan as above for liver.
   Continue to monitor for encephalopathy/signs of stroke.
   #. Anemia: Has been trending down. Not currently concerned for bleeding
   however will continue to monitor.
   - minimize phlebotomy
   - will plan to transfuse 1u PRBC with HD
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Trending down off steroids and ongoing ABx treatment.  Peak WBC had
   been 28, currently 11.
   - s/p vanco/cefepime for HAP
   - discontinued vori (was for possible invasive aspergilliosis, and may
   start alternative in the future)
   - cont amphotericin
   - f/u cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   - c.diff negative
   - could restart vori for long-term treatment of aspergilliosis
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of
   anticoagulation.
   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis
   MWF.  Nephrology following.
   - ongoing UF dialysis, plan HD MWF
   - nephrocaps
   - f/u nephrology recs
   - daily weights
   #.  Thrombocytopenia.:  Stable.  HIT neg and resolving
   thrombocytopenia.  Daily CBC
   FEN: TF through NGT
   Prophylaxis:  Pneumoboots for DVT prophylaxis, PPI, stooling

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic heart failure, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, malnutrition, and recurrent respiratory distress secondary to right lower lobe (RLL) lobar collapse. She has a known diagnosis of invasive aspergilliosis and has been treated with voriconazole, which was discontinued due to elevated liver function tests (LFTs).

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress, and her respiratory status is tenuous.
2. NSVT/Afib: The patient has known atrial fibrillation (AFib) and has had episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) coinciding with dialysis. She was given amiodarone, which improved her ectopy.
3. HTN/Hypotension: The patient has labile blood pressure, with episodes of hypertension and hypotension. She is currently hypotensive and is being managed with metoprolol, neo, and replacement of her arterial line.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient has rising LFTs, which have peaked in the thousands. The cause is unclear, but it may be related to hypotensive/shock liver or medication toxicity. She is currently on liposomal amphotericin and is being monitored for liver function.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is trending down, and she is not currently concerned for bleeding. However, she will continue to be monitored.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is trending down off steroids and ongoing antibacterial treatment.
7. RUE DVT: The patient has a DVT in her right upper extremity, which may increase her risk of pulmonary embolism (PE). However, she was intolerant of anticoagulation.
8. ESRD on HD: The patient has been on dialysis since her recent colectomy and receives dialysis three times a week.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is stable and resolving.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and she may require another intubation.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has known AFib and has had episodes of NSVT. She may require further management of her cardiac rhythm.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if she develops sepsis or other complications.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver dysfunction may progress, leading to liver failure.
5. Invasive aspergilliosis: The patient has a known diagnosis of invasive aspergilliosis, and her treatment plan may need to be adjusted if her condition worsens.
6. PE: The patient's DVT may increase her risk of PE, which could be fatal if left untreated.
7. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may increase her risk of bleeding, particularly if she develops a gastrointestinal bleed.
8. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and invasive aspergilliosis make her at risk for infection, particularly with fungal pathogens.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring her closely and adjusting her treatment plan as needed to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic heart failure, end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, malnutrition, and recurrent respiratory distress secondary to right lower lobe lobar collapse.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress, and is currently extubated. She has been treated with oral voriconazole for possible invasive aspergilliosis, but it was discontinued due to elevated liver enzymes. She is now restarting voriconazole.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has been hypotensive and tachypnic, with a blood pressure of 132/41 mmHg and a heart rate of 78 bpm. She has been receiving fluids and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.
* Liver: The patient has had rising liver enzymes, which have peaked in the thousands. The liver enzymes are now trending downward, and the patient is restarting voriconazole.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has dropped, and she is being monitored for possible bleeding complications.
* AFib: The patient has had episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and atrial fibrillation (AFib), which have been treated with amiodarone and metoprolol.
* HTN/Hypotension: The patient has had labile blood pressure, with episodes of hypertension and hypotension.
* AMS: The patient has had altered mental status, which is likely related to liver damage and hypotension.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is trending downward, and she has received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is trending down, and she is being monitored for possible infection.
* RUE DVT: The patient has a right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is being treated with prophylactic measures.
* ESRD on HD: The patient is on hemodialysis three times a week and is being monitored by nephrology.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's recurrent lobar collapse and respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Bleeding complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and history of bleeding complications may increase the risk of bleeding.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver enzymes are still elevated, and further liver damage may occur.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's AFib and NSVT may worsen, leading to cardiac complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.
* Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and history of infection may increase the risk of infection.
* DVT/PE: The patient's RUE DVT may progress to a pulmonary embolism (PE), which could be life-threatening.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
* Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to encephalopathy.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of her respiratory, hemodynamic, liver, and cardiac status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-inch tall individual who weighs 65.6 kg (admission weight: 65.5 kg). They are currently receiving non-invasive ventilation and have a SpO2 of 100%. The patient has a sinus rhythm, with a heart rate of 78 bpm and blood pressure of 132/41 mmHg.

The patient has a history of liver function abnormalities, impaired skin integrity, electrolyte and fluid disorder, deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity, pain control, cardiac dysrhythmia, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and bacteremia.

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.9-16.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.6-10.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 60-118 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8-2.4 mg/dL
* Glucose: 115-153 mg/dL
* Other lab results include elevated liver enzymes, abnormal coagulation studies, and elevated inflammatory markers.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their altered mental status, and therefore, the following assessments were not performed: peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, and abdominal examinations.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: worsening of oxygenation, increased risk of pneumonia, and potential need for invasive ventilation
* Acute kidney injury: worsening of renal function, electrolyte imbalance, and potential need for dialysis
* Cardiac dysrhythmia: worsening of cardiac function, increased risk of cardiac arrest, and potential need for cardiac intervention
* Liver dysfunction: worsening of liver function, increased risk of bleeding, and potential need for liver transplantation
* Deep venous thrombosis: worsening of clotting, increased risk of pulmonary embolism, and potential need for anticoagulation therapy
* Bacteremia: worsening of sepsis, increased risk of organ failure, and potential need for antibiotic therapy

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to continue monitoring their vital signs, lab results, and physical examination findings closely to identify any potential complications and adjust their treatment plan accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male admitted to the ICU with severe sepsis, acute kidney injury, and liver dysfunction. The patient has been receiving non-invasive ventilation and has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin and voriconazole. The patient's blood pressure has been hypotensive, requiring pressors, and has been managed with fluid boluses and vasopressors. The patient's respiratory status has been improving, with a recent decrease in oxygen requirements.

The patient has developed several complications, including:

* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity, which is unable to be anticoagulated
* Liver function abnormalities, which are improving but may be ischemic in origin
* Thrombocytopenia, which is being managed with transfusions
* Acute kidney injury, which is being managed with hemodialysis
* Anemia, which was transfused yesterday
* Respiratory distress, which is being managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and may require invasive ventilation

Potential Medical Complications:

* Progressive respiratory failure requiring invasive ventilation
* Further decline in liver function leading to coagulopathy and bleeding
* Development of septic shock due to ongoing sepsis
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and anticoagulation therapy
* Development of further complications related to acute kidney injury, such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis
* Increased risk of infection due to immunosuppression and prolonged ICU stay
* Development of further complications related to liver dysfunction, such as encephalopathy and coagulopathy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical complications. Here is a summary of the patient's condition:

* Respiratory: The patient is receiving non-invasive ventilation and has a history of respiratory distress, which may be related to lower lobe volume loss or potential invasive aspergillus infection.
* Hemodynamic: The patient has been hypotensive during HD and has required brief use of pressors.
* Liver: The patient has liver function abnormalities, which are improving but appear to be of ischemic origin.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and they are being followed off of Ambisome.
* Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a DVT in their upper extremity and is unable to receive anticoagulation.
* Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure and is receiving HD. Anti-hypertensives are being held on HD days.
* Anemia: The patient has been transfused with blood products and has a low hemoglobin level.
* Other: The patient has a PICC line, dialysis catheter, and arterial line in place.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Worsening respiratory distress, potentially requiring invasive ventilation or surgical intervention.
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to ongoing infections, including potential invasive aspergillus infection.
* Progression of liver dysfunction, potentially leading to liver failure.
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and ongoing anticoagulation therapy.
* Complications related to DVT, including pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
* Worsening renal function, potentially leading to end-stage renal disease.
* Development of electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disorders due to ongoing medical therapy.
* Increased risk of infection, including catheter-related infections or line sepsis.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-inch tall individual weighing 65.6 kg, admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, hypotension, liver function abnormalities, thrombocytopenia, deep venous thrombosis (DVT), cardiac dysrhythmia, respiratory distress, and acute renal failure. The patient has undergone dialysis, has an arterial line, and is receiving prophylactic treatment for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.9°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, and blood pressure of 132/41 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's history of bacteremia and altered mental status, there is a high risk of developing sepsis.
2. Bleeding: Thrombocytopenia increases the risk of bleeding, especially with invasive procedures or medications that can cause bleeding.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to AKI.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress may progress to respiratory failure if not properly managed.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac dysrhythmia may worsen or lead to cardiac arrest if not properly managed.
6. Liver Failure: The patient's liver function abnormalities may worsen, leading to liver failure.
7. DVT: The patient's DVT may progress to pulmonary embolism if not properly managed.
8. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and bacteremia increase the risk of developing new infections.
9. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
10. Malnutrition: The patient's poor nutritional status may worsen if not properly managed, leading to malnutrition and its associated complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-inch tall adult with a weight of 65.6 kg, who is currently in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.2°C (95.3°F)
* Heart rate: 78 bpm (74-97 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 132/41 mmHg (69-181/35-91 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 inspirations per minute (20-47 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus Rhythm

The patient has undergone various interventions, including:

* Non-invasive ventilation, which was started on 04/23 at 01:33 PM and stopped at 05:00 PM
* Arterial line insertion on 04/23 at 12:00 PM
* Hemodialysis (HD) with temporary use of pressors
* Infusions of various medications, including antibiotics and antifungals
* Transfusion of blood products

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 60 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 115 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
* Liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevated levels of alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST)
* Coagulation studies show prolonged prothrombin time (PT), partial thromboplastin time (PTT), and international normalized ratio (INR)

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypotension, which has improved, but will require continued monitoring
* Liver function abnormalities, which are improving and are suspected to be ischemic in origin
* Thrombocytopenia, which is being followed off of amphotericin B
* Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity, which is unable to be anti-coagulated
* Respiratory distress, which is related to lower lobe volume loss and may be related to invasive aspergillus infection or staphylococcal pneumonia
* Acute renal failure, which is being treated with hemodialysis and will require continued management
* Anemia, which has been transfused
* Nutrition is being provided through total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
* Glycemic control is being monitored and managed with insulin as needed

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further deterioration of liver function, leading to increased risk of bleeding and coagulopathy
* Development of respiratory failure, which may require invasive mechanical ventilation
* Progression of renal failure, leading to increased risk of electrolyte imbalances and cardiovascular complications
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy
* Development of sepsis, which may be related to invasive aspergillus infection or staphylococcal pneumonia
* Further complications from DVT, such as pulmonary embolism or post-thrombotic syndrome.

   81 yo f with HTN, HL, CHF, ESRD on HD, malnutrition, here with
   recurrent respiratory distress secondary to RLL lobar collapse (?TBM vs
   aspiration with mucous plugging vs HAP) now extubated.
   .
   #.  Respiratory failure:
   Patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress.
   Reportedly has TBM but left sided lesion is too distal to stent. Has
   positive glucan/galactomannan, and CT on [**4-14**] showing diffuse disease,
   possibly invasive aspergilliosis. Was started on oral voriconazole on
   [**2190-4-15**], but with elevated LFT
s to thousands; vori was discontinued.
   Due to multiple respiratory problems, patient may ultimately require
   another intubation which she has stated she would want.  Will continue
   to remove fluid as possible with dialysis. Must also consider that some
   component of resp failure could be PE from known RUE DVT, though did
   not tolerate anticoagulation.  Tenuous respiratory status overall today
   and is visibly tired and tachypnic.  Now off steroids. CT sinus showing
   fluid in mastoids not concerning for invasive fungal disease there. Did
   benefit from periodic BIPAP yesterday. Has new MRSA growing in sputum.
   - completed course for HAP with Vancomycin (D1 [**4-10**]) & cefepime (D1
   [**4-9**]), both d/c
d on [**4-17**]
   - gave vanc dose for MRSA in sputum, this will last until dialysis
   Monday, check vanc level. Will need to decide over the weekend whether
   to commit to another course of vanc
   - initially discontinued Voriconazole (D1 was [**4-16**]) due to LFT elevation
   now LFT
s normal and will restart vori today ([**4-24**], see below)
   - d/c liposomal ampho (D1 was [**4-20**])
   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - PT
   - failed speech and swallow eval.
   - consider non-invasive ventilation, CPAP today at 5 and can go up as
   needed
   - resend ABG
   - consider repeat CT, though patient would not be able to tolerate the
   study at this time.
   #.  Thrombocytopenia.:  Dropped today.  HIT neg. Possibly due to
   Amphoterocin.
   - Discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori as LFT
s have improved.
   - cont to monitor
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol on [**4-23**] before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker as needed after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. HTN/Hypotension.  On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on
   captopril and amlodipine here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **]
   beta-blocker given concurrent rhythm issues.  In ICU has had very
   labile hypertensive blood pressure but is hypotensive
   today/normotensive today
   - will control on metoprolol as needed on non-HD days as per above
   - can restart neo as needed to maintain perfusion
   - maintain a-line for now
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #. Liver:
   Patient has had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Med effect vs.
   hypotensive/shock liver. Vori was discontinued, and liposomal
   amphoterocin started. Will cont to support pressures to keep SBP above
   100.  Downward trending LFT
s since period of hypotension.  Now today
   has low platlets, concerning for Amphoterocin effect
   - Hepatology signed off.  LFT
s improving, likely related to ischemic
   liver
   - liver US with dopplers
 Normal right lobe of the liver, limited view
   of the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - ammonia nml
   - cont to trend LFT
   - discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori due to concern for low
   platlets, now that LFT
s are improving vori is restarted

   Given timing with liver damage, likely related. [**Month (only) 51**] be encephalopathy
   vs. hypotension/hypoxia. CT scan negative.  Plan as above for liver.
   Continue to monitor for encephalopathy/signs of stroke.
   #. Anemia: Has been trending down. Not currently concerned for bleeding
   however will continue to monitor. Transfused 1u PRBC with HD on [**4-23**].
   - minimize phlebotomy
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Trending down off steroids and ongoing ABx treatment.  Peak WBC had
   been 28. c.diff negative
   - s/p vanco/cefepime for HAP
   - back on vori (for possible invasive aspergilliosis)
   - discontinue amphotericin
   - f/u cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of

   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo f with HTN, HL, CHF, ESRD on HD, malnutrition, here with
   recurrent respiratory distress secondary to RLL lobar collapse (?TBM vs
   aspiration with mucous plugging vs HAP) now extubated.
   .
   #.  Respiratory failure:
   Patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress.
   Reportedly has TBM but left sided lesion is too distal to stent. Has
   positive glucan/galactomannan, and CT on [**4-14**] showing diffuse disease,
   possibly invasive aspergilliosis. Was started on oral voriconazole on
   [**2190-4-15**], but with elevated LFT
s to thousands; vori was discontinued.
   Due to multiple respiratory problems, patient may ultimately require
   another intubation which she has stated she would want.  Will continue
   to remove fluid as possible with dialysis. Must also consider that some
   component of resp failure could be PE from known RUE DVT, though did
   not tolerate anticoagulation.  Tenuous respiratory status overall today
   and is visibly tired and tachypnic.  Now off steroids. CT sinus showing
   fluid in mastoids not concerning for invasive fungal disease there. Did
   benefit from periodic BIPAP yesterday. Has new MRSA growing in sputum.
   - completed course for HAP with Vancomycin (D1 [**4-10**]) & cefepime (D1
   [**4-9**]), both d/c
d on [**4-17**]
   - gave vanc dose for MRSA in sputum, this will last until dialysis
   Monday, check vanc level. Will need to decide over the weekend whether
   to commit to another course of vanc
   - initially discontinued Voriconazole (D1 was [**4-16**]) due to LFT elevation
   now LFT
s normal and will restart vori today ([**4-24**], see below)
   - d/c liposomal ampho (D1 was [**4-20**])
   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - PT
   - failed speech and swallow eval.
   - consider non-invasive ventilation, CPAP today at 5 and can go up as
   needed
   - resend ABG
   - consider repeat CT, though patient would not be able to tolerate the
   study at this time.
   #.  Thrombocytopenia.:  Dropped today.  HIT neg. Possibly due to
   Amphoterocin.
   - Discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori as LFT
s have improved.
   - cont to monitor
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol on [**4-23**] before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker as needed after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. HTN/Hypotension.  On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on
   captopril and amlodipine here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **]
   beta-blocker given concurrent rhythm issues.  In ICU has had very
   labile hypertensive blood pressure but is hypotensive
   today/normotensive today
   - will control on metoprolol as needed on non-HD days as per above
   - can restart neo as needed to maintain perfusion
   - maintain a-line for now
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #. Liver:
   Patient has had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Med effect vs.
   hypotensive/shock liver. Vori was discontinued, and liposomal
   amphoterocin started. Will cont to support pressures to keep SBP above
   100.  Downward trending LFT
s since period of hypotension.  Now today
   has low platlets, concerning for Amphoterocin effect
   - Hepatology signed off.  LFT
s improving, likely related to ischemic
   liver
   - liver US with dopplers
 Normal right lobe of the liver, limited view
   of the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - ammonia nml
   - cont to trend LFT
   - discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori due to concern for low
   platlets, now that LFT
s are improving vori is restarted
   # AMS:
   Given timing with liver damage, likely related. [**Month (only) 51**] be encephalopathy
   vs. hypotension/hypoxia. CT scan negative.  Plan as above for liver.
   Continue to monitor for encephalopathy/signs of stroke.
   #. Anemia: Has been trending down. Not currently concerned for bleeding
   however will continue to monitor. Transfused 1u PRBC with HD on [**4-23**].
   - minimize phlebotomy
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Trending down off steroids and ongoing ABx treatment.  Peak WBC had
   been 28. c.diff negative
   - s/p vanco/cefepime for HAP
   - back on vori (for possible invasive aspergilliosis)
   - discontinue amphotericin
   - f/u cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of
   anticoagulation.
   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis
   MWF.  Nephrology following.
   - ongoing UF dialysis, plan HD MWF
   - nephrocaps
   - f/u nephrology recs
   - daily weights
   - d/c foley as does not make significant urine
   FEN: TF through NGT
   Prophylaxis:  Pneumoboots for DVT prophylaxis, PPI, stooling
   Code: Full
   Access: PICC.
   Dispo: ICU for now, with plan for acute care facility after ICU.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic heart failure, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis. She was admitted to the ICU with recurrent respiratory distress secondary to right lower lobe lobar collapse, possibly due to tuberculosis, aspiration, or hospital-acquired pneumonia. She has been treated with voriconazole, but it was discontinued due to elevated liver enzymes. She has also been treated with vancomycin and cefepime for hospital-acquired pneumonia.

Current Status:

The patient is currently on voriconazole, which was restarted after liver enzymes improved. She is also receiving antifungal treatment for possible invasive aspergillosis. Her respiratory status is tenuous, and she is requiring CPAP support. She has a history of thrombocytopenia, which is being monitored. Her liver enzymes are trending downward, and she is being supported with dialysis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and she may require another intubation.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and she may be at risk for bleeding.
3. Hypertension/Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and she may require further management.
4. Liver damage: The patient's liver enzymes are trending downward, but she may still be at risk for further damage.
5. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin is trending downward, and she may require further transfusions.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is trending down, but she may still be at risk for infection.
7. RUE DVT: The patient has a history of DVT, which may increase her risk for pulmonary embolism.
8. ESRD on HD: The patient is on hemodialysis, which may increase her risk for complications such as infection and bleeding.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and she may require another intubation. Her thrombocytopenia is being monitored, and she is receiving antifungal treatment for possible invasive aspergillosis. Her liver enzymes are trending downward, and she is being supported with dialysis. Her anemia is being monitored, and she may require further transfusions. Her leukocytosis is trending down, but she may still be at risk for infection. Her RUE DVT is being monitored, and she is receiving prophylactic treatment for DVT. Her ESRD on HD is being managed, and she is receiving ongoing care from nephrology.

The patient is a 61-inch tall, 65.6 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, liver function abnormalities, impaired skin integrity, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity. The patient has been receiving voriconazole for suspected fungal infection and has been on tube feeds. The patient's vital signs have been stable, with a temperature range of 35.6-36.9°C, heart rate of 89-100 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/43-143/56 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status has been improving, with a decrease in CPAP pressure from 5 to 8 cmH2O. The patient's laboratory results have shown improvements in liver function, with a decrease in bilirubin and an increase in albumin. The patient's electrolyte levels have been stable, with a slight decrease in potassium and an increase in sodium. The patient's WBC count has been increasing, with a current count of 15.0 K/uL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk for developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he is still at risk for developing respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and death.
3. Cardiac Dysrhythmia: The patient has a history of cardiac dysrhythmia, which can lead to cardiac arrest and death.
4. Renal Failure: The patient has a history of acute renal failure, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and death.
5. DVT: The patient has a DVT in the upper extremity, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death.
6. Liver Failure: The patient has liver function abnormalities, which can lead to liver failure and death.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of fungal infection, which can lead to sepsis and death.
8. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hemorrhage and death.
9. Hypotension: The patient has a history of hypotension, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes in his condition.
2. Continue to provide aggressive treatment for the patient's fungal infection, including voriconazole and other antifungal medications.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide oxygen therapy as needed to prevent respiratory failure.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and provide cardioversion as needed to prevent cardiac dysrhythmia.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and provide dialysis as needed to prevent renal failure.
6. Monitor the patient's DVT closely and provide anticoagulation therapy as needed to prevent pulmonary embolism.
7. Monitor the patient's liver function closely and provide liver support therapy as needed to prevent liver failure.
8. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and provide gastroprotective therapy as needed to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and provide vasopressors as needed to prevent hypotension.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-inch tall, 65.6 kg male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status, liver function abnormalities, impaired skin integrity, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.6°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/43 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 70%.

The patient's laboratory results show abnormal liver function tests, including elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia. The patient's blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating acute kidney injury.

The patient's physical examination reveals coarse breath sounds, expiratory wheezes, and distant heart sounds. The patient's abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended, with bowel sounds present.

The patient's medical history includes a history of bacteremia, and the patient is currently receiving voriconazole for suspected MRSA bacteremia. The patient's medication list includes voriconazole, phenylephrine, and other ICU medications.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP with a high FiO2, which may increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac dysrhythmia: The patient's electrolyte imbalance and liver dysfunction may increase the risk of cardiac dysrhythmia.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver dysfunction may worsen, leading to liver failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and electrolyte imbalance may increase the risk of sepsis.
6. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's DVT in the upper extremity may worsen, leading to pulmonary embolism or other complications.
7. Pressure ulcers: The patient's impaired skin integrity may increase the risk of pressure ulcers.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve the patient's outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo f with HTN, HL, CHF, ESRD on HD, malnutrition, here with
   recurrent respiratory distress secondary to RLL lobar collapse (?TBM vs
   aspiration with mucous plugging vs HAP) now extubated.
   #.  Respiratory failure:
   Patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress.
   Reportedly has TBM but left sided lesion is too distal to stent. Has
   positive glucan/galactomannan, and CT on [**4-14**] showing diffuse disease,
   possibly invasive aspergilliosis. Was started on oral voriconazole on
   [**2190-4-15**], but with elevated LFT
s to thousands; vori was discontinued
   and ambisome was started. Voriconazole was restarted on [**2190-4-24**].
   Completed course for HAP with Vancomycin (D1 [**4-10**]) & cefepime (D1
   [**4-9**]), both d/c
d on [**4-17**]. Due to multiple respiratory problems, patient
   may ultimately require another intubation which she has stated she
   would want.  Will continue to remove fluid as possible with dialysis.
   Must also consider that some component of resp failure could be PE from
   known RUE DVT, though did not tolerate anticoagulation. On periodic
   CPAP Has new MRSA growing in sputum.
   - Vanc dosing at HD protocol
   - Continue voriconazole
   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - consider non-invasive ventilation, CPAP at 8 as needed today
   #.  Thrombocytopenia:
   Platelets have dropped acutely from 118 5 days ago to 55 today. HIT
   neg. Possibly due to Amphoterocin. No drop in HCT to suggest TTP,
   though should check a smear.
   - Add-on smear to morning labs
   - Discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori as LFT
s have improved.
   - cont to monitor
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol on [**4-23**] before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker as needed after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. HTN/Hypotension:
   On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on captopril and amlodipine
   here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **] beta-blocker given concurrent
   rhythm issues.  In ICU has had labile blood pressure. Normotensive this
   AM.
   - will control on metoprolol as needed on non-HD days as per above
   - can restart neo as needed to maintain perfusion
   - maintain a-line for now
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #. Liver:
   Patient had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Though to be shock
   liver due to hypotension following HD. Vori was discontinued, and
   liposomal amphoterocin started. Now that liver enzymes have recovered
   to ALT = 410, AST = 60 have discontinued amphoterocin andrestarted
   voriconazole. Will cont to support pressures to keep SBP above 100.
   Liver ultrasound showed normal right lobe of the liver, limited view of
   the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - cont to trend LFTs now that voriconazole restarted
   # AMS:
   Appears to be related to periods of hypotension.
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Peak WBC had been 28. Is 15 today and has been fluctuating in last 5
   days. Is now back on voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis. Also
   restarted Vancomycin for MRSA positive sputum.
   - follow-up cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of
   anticoagulation.
   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis
   MWF.  Nephrology following.
   - ongoing UF dialysis, plan HD MWF
   - nephrocaps
   - f/u nephrology recs
   - daily weights

   Eos:1.1 %, D-dimer:5524 ng/mL, Fibrinogen:331 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:1.9
   mmol/L, Albumin:2.7 g/dL, LDH:546 IU/L, Ca++:9.3 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL,
   PO4:3.8 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo f with HTN, HL, CHF, ESRD on HD, malnutrition, here with
   recurrent respiratory distress secondary to RLL lobar collapse (?TBM vs
   aspiration with mucous plugging vs HAP) now extubated.
   #.  Respiratory failure:
   Patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress.
   Reportedly has TBM but left sided lesion is too distal to stent. Has
   positive glucan/galactomannan, and CT on [**4-14**] showing diffuse disease,
   possibly invasive aspergilliosis. Was started on oral voriconazole on
   [**2190-4-15**], but with elevated LFT
s to thousands; vori was discontinued
   and ambisome was started. Voriconazole was restarted on [**2190-4-24**].
   Completed course for HAP with Vancomycin (D1 [**4-10**]) & cefepime (D1
   [**4-9**]), both d/c
d on [**4-17**]. Due to multiple respiratory problems, patient
   may ultimately require another intubation which she has stated she
   would want.  Will continue to remove fluid as possible with dialysis.
   Must also consider that some component of resp failure could be PE from
   known RUE DVT, though did not tolerate anticoagulation. On periodic
   CPAP Has new MRSA growing in sputum.
   - Vanc dosing at HD protocol
   - Continue voriconazole
   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - consider non-invasive ventilation, CPAP at 8 as needed today
   #.  Thrombocytopenia:
   Platelets have dropped acutely from 118 5 days ago to 55 today. HIT
   neg. Possibly due to Amphoterocin. No drop in HCT to suggest TTP,
   though should check a smear.
   - Add-on smear to morning labs
   - Discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori as LFT
s have improved.
   - cont to monitor
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol on [**4-23**] before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker as needed after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. HTN/Hypotension:
   On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on captopril and amlodipine
   here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **] beta-blocker given concurrent
   rhythm issues.  In ICU has had labile blood pressure. Normotensive this
   AM.
   - will control on metoprolol as needed on non-HD days as per above
   - can restart neo as needed to maintain perfusion
   - maintain a-line for now
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #. Liver:
   Patient had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Though to be shock
   liver due to hypotension following HD. Vori was discontinued, and
   liposomal amphoterocin started. Now that liver enzymes have recovered
   to ALT = 410, AST = 60 have discontinued amphoterocin andrestarted
   voriconazole. Will cont to support pressures to keep SBP above 100.
   Liver ultrasound showed normal right lobe of the liver, limited view of
   the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - cont to trend LFTs now that voriconazole restarted
   # AMS:
   Appears to be related to periods of hypotension.
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Peak WBC had been 28. Is 15 today and has been fluctuating in last 5
   days. Is now back on voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis. Also
   restarted Vancomycin for MRSA positive sputum.
   - follow-up cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of
   anticoagulation.
   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis
   MWF.  Nephrology following.
   - ongoing UF dialysis, plan HD MWF
   - nephrocaps
   - f/u nephrology recs
   - daily weights
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic heart failure, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis. She is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to recurrent respiratory distress secondary to right lower lobe (RLL) lobar collapse, possibly due to tuberculosis (TBM), aspiration with mucous plugging, or hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

The patient's recent laboratory results show:

* Elevated liver enzymes (LFTs) in the thousands, which have now recovered to normal levels
* Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 55
* Leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15
* Elevated troponin-T and CK-MB, indicating possible cardiac damage
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP), indicating possible liver or bone disease

The patient's current medical issues include:

* Respiratory failure: Recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress, possibly due to TBM, aspiration, or HAP
* Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count has dropped acutely, possibly due to amphoterocin
* NSVT/Afib: Patient has known atrial fibrillation and has had episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) during dialysis
* HTN/Hypotension: Patient has labile blood pressure, requiring careful management
* Liver: Patient had rising LFTs, which have now recovered to normal levels
* AMS: Patient appears to be related to periods of hypotension
* Leukocytosis: Patient has a fluctuating white blood cell count
* RUE DVT: Patient has a right upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is at risk for pulmonary embolism (PE)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis and MRSA-positive sputum
* Vancomycin for MRSA-positive sputum
* Discontinuation of amphoterocin due to thrombocytopenia
* Restart of voriconazole after LFTs recovered to normal levels
* Continue to monitor liver enzymes, platelet count, and white blood cell count
* Consider non-invasive ventilation and CPAP as needed
* Plan for beta-blocker as needed after hemodialysis to control atrial fibrillation
* Restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Patient may require reintubation due to recurrent lobar collapse and respiratory distress
* Thrombocytopenia: Patient may be at risk for bleeding complications due to low platelet count
* NSVT/Afib: Patient may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications
* HTN/Hypotension: Patient may be at risk for hypotensive episodes and cardiac complications
* Liver: Patient may be at risk for liver damage or failure due to ongoing liver disease
* AMS: Patient may be at risk for altered mental status due to hypotension or other medical complications
* Leukocytosis: Patient may be at risk for infection due to fluctuating white blood cell count
* RUE DVT: Patient may be at risk for pulmonary embolism due to right upper extremity DVT

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of her complex medical issues to prevent potential complications and improve her outcomes.

* Sepsis due to invasive aspergillus infection

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is receiving CPAP/PSV with an FiO2 of 70% and is stable, with a SpO2 of 99%. The patient has lower lobe volume loss and is at risk for invasive aspergillus infection.
* Hemodynamic: The patient has hypotension, which has improved, and is being monitored closely.
* Liver function: The patient has liver function abnormalities, which are improving, and are likely ischemic in origin.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 55, which is decreasing, and is likely related to the discontinuation of Ampho.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure and is receiving hemodialysis.
* Anemia: The patient has been transfused and is now stable.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a heart rate of 89 bpm and a blood pressure of 124/43 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of further deterioration due to the lower lobe volume loss and potential invasive aspergillus infection.
* Sepsis: The patient has a risk of developing sepsis due to the presence of staph in the sputum and the possibility of invasive aspergillus infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and continued use of anticoagulant medications increase the risk of bleeding.
* Renal failure progression: The patient's acute renal failure may progress, requiring further hemodialysis and potentially impacting overall health.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver function abnormalities may worsen, potentially leading to liver failure.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's hypotension and cardiovascular instability increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrest.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory status. Additionally, the patient's anticoagulant and antibiotic regimens should be carefully managed to minimize the risk of bleeding and sepsis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical condition. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F) with a current temperature of 35.6°C (96°F)
* Heart rate: 89 beats per minute (bpm) with a range of 77-100 bpm
* Blood pressure: 124/43 mmHg with a range of 108/33-143/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 inspirations per minute (insp/min) with a range of 19-35 insp/min
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient has several medical conditions, including:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is within the normal range, but it has improved.
2. Liver function abnormalities: The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevations in bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The patient is tolerating voriconazole, and the liver function is improving.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, with a nadir of 55 x 10^9/L. The patient is off amphotericin B, and the thrombocytopenia may be consumptive.
4. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity: The patient has a DVT that cannot be anticoagulated.
5. Respiratory distress: The patient has lower lobe volume loss, which may be related to invasive Aspergillus infection. The patient is being treated with voriconazole, and the respiratory distress is improving.
6. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine is elevated, and he is on hemodialysis (HD). The patient's anti-hypertensives are being held on HD days.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin is low, and he was transfused 2 days ago. His anemia is now stable.
8. Pheochromocytoma (PAF): The patient is being treated with lopressor as needed.

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 10.6-16.4 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.8-9.3 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 55-107 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.8-2.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26-44 mg/dL
* Glucose: 115-172 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 546 IU/L
* Calcium: 9.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.8 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Voriconazole
* Vancomycin
* Lopressor
* Amphotericin B
* HD
* Anti-hypertensives
* Anti-coagulants
* Pain medications

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue voriconazole and vancomycin
2. Wean oxygen as tolerated
3. Continue CPAP as needed
4. Hold anti-hypertensives on HD days
5. Monitor for signs of bleeding or thrombocytopenia
6. Continue HD
7. Monitor for signs of respiratory distress or infection
8. Continue lopressor as needed

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Bleeding or thrombocytopenia due to the patient's low platelet count
2. Respiratory distress or infection due to the patient's underlying medical conditions
3. Renal failure or worsening of ARF due to the patient's decreased kidney function
4. Anemia or worsening of anemia due to the patient's low hemoglobin level
5. Pheochromocytoma crisis due to the patient's underlying condition
6. Deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to the patient's immobility and underlying medical conditions
7. Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's underlying medical conditions and potential infections.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-inch tall, 65.6 kg male who has been admitted to the ICU for 7 days. He is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a Vt of 1,861 mL, PS of 10 cmH2O, and PEEP of 8 cmH2O. His FiO2 is 70%, and his SpO2 is 99%. He is also receiving infusions of Ambisome, vancomycin, and voriconazole.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.6°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/43 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 23 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 99%.

The patient has a history of liver function abnormalities, which are improving, and thrombocytopenia, which is being managed with transfusions. He also has a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in his upper extremity, which is not being anticoagulated due to the risk of bleeding. He has respiratory distress related to lower lobe volume loss, and there is a possibility of invasive aspergillus infection or staphylococcal pneumonia.

The patient has acute renal failure, which is being managed with hemodialysis (HD). He has also been transfused with blood products, including platelets and red blood cells.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Bleeding complications due to thrombocytopenia and the use of anticoagulants.
2. Respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying respiratory disease and the use of mechanical ventilation.
3. Sepsis or septic shock due to the possibility of invasive aspergillus infection or staphylococcal pneumonia.
4. Acute kidney injury or worsening of chronic kidney disease due to the use of nephrotoxic medications or the patient's underlying kidney disease.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer prophylaxis or the use of anticoagulants.
6. Cardiovascular instability due to the patient's underlying cardiovascular disease and the use of vasopressors.
7. Neurological complications due to the patient's underlying neurological disease and the use of sedatives or anesthetics.
8. Infection or sepsis due to the use of central venous catheters or other invasive devices.
9. Bleeding complications due to the patient's underlying coagulopathy and the use of anticoagulants.
10. Worsening of the patient's underlying liver disease due to the use of medications or the patient's underlying liver disease.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo f with HTN, HL, CHF, ESRD on HD, malnutrition, here with
   recurrent respiratory distress secondary to RLL lobar collapse (?TBM vs
   aspiration with mucous plugging vs HAP) now extubated.
   #.  Respiratory failure:
   Patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress.
   Reportedly has TBM but left sided lesion is too distal to stent. Has
   positive glucan/galactomannan, and CT on [**4-14**] showing diffuse disease,
   possibly invasive aspergilliosis. Was started on oral voriconazole on
   [**2190-4-15**], but with elevated LFT
s to thousands; vori was discontinued
   and ambisome was started. Voriconazole was restarted on [**2190-4-24**].
   Completed course for HAP with Vancomycin (D1 [**4-10**]) & cefepime (D1
   [**4-9**]), both d/c
d on [**4-17**]. Due to multiple respiratory problems, patient
   may ultimately require another intubation which she has stated she
   would want.  Will continue to remove fluid as possible with dialysis.
   Must also consider that some component of resp failure could be PE from
   known RUE DVT, though did not tolerate anticoagulation. On periodic
   CPAP Has new MRSA growing in sputum.
   - Vanc dosing at HD protocol
   - Continue voriconazole
   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - consider non-invasive ventilation, CPAP at 8 as needed today
   #. HTN/Hypotension:
   On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on captopril and amlodipine
   here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **] beta-blocker given concurrent
   rhythm issues.  In ICU has had labile blood pressure.  Significant
   labile BP
s with HD, this AM with hypotension  requiring Neo for BP
   support despite Midodrine given prior to HD.
   - will d/w renal options for better BP control during HD.
   - will control on metoprolol as needed on non-HD days as per above
   - Neo for BP control during HD
   - maintain a-line for now
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #.  Thrombocytopenia:
   Platelets have dropped acutely from 118 5 days ago to 55 today. HIT
   neg. Possibly due to Amphoterocin. No drop in HCT to suggest TTP,
   though should check a smear.
   - Add-on smear to morning labs
   - cont Voriconazole
   - daily LFT
   - cont to monitor
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol on [**4-23**] before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker as needed after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. Liver:
   Patient had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Though to be shock
   liver due to hypotension following HD. Vori was discontinued, and
   liposomal amphoterocin started. Now that liver enzymes have recovered
   to ALT = 410, AST = 60 have discontinued amphoterocin andrestarted
   voriconazole. Will cont to support pressures to keep SBP above 100.
   Liver ultrasound showed normal right lobe of the liver, limited view of
   the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - cont to trend LFTs now that voriconazole restarted
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Peak WBC had been 28. Is 15 today and has been fluctuating in last 5
   days. Is now back on voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis. Also
   restarted Vancomycin for MRSA positive sputum.
   - follow-up cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of
   anticoagulation.  Patient with new complaint of bilateral calf pain
   this AM, exam without swelling or cellulitis.
   - BLE U/S for r/o DVT
   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis
   MWF.  Nephrology following.
   - ongoing UF dialysis, plan HD MWF
   - nephrocaps
   - f/u nephrology recs
   - daily weights

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old female with a complex medical history, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic heart failure, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, malnutrition, and recurrent respiratory distress. She has been admitted to the ICU with recurrent lobar collapse, possibly due to tuberculosis (TBM), invasive aspergillosis, or aspiration with mucous plugging.

The patient has been treated with voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis, but it was discontinued due to elevated liver function tests (LFTs) and restarted after liver enzymes recovered. She has also been treated with Ambisome, and voriconazole was restarted on the 24th.

The patient has been experiencing labile blood pressure, with episodes of hypotension requiring Neo for BP support. She has been treated with nitropaste and amlodipine at home and has been switched to a single beta-blocker in the ICU.

The patient has been experiencing thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count dropping from 118 to 55. HIT has been ruled out, and the cause is possibly due to Amphoterocin. She has been treated with voriconazole and has been monitoring her platelet count.

The patient has been experiencing atrial fibrillation (AFib) and has been treated with amiodarone. She has also been experiencing NSVT, which has improved with the treatment. The patient has been intolerant of anticoagulation due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.

The patient has been experiencing leukocytosis, with a peak WBC of 28. She has been treated with voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis and has been restarted on Vancomycin for MRSA-positive sputum.

The patient has a history of ESRD on HD and has been on dialysis since her recent colectomy. She has been experiencing bilateral calf pain and has been ordered to have a BLE ultrasound for r/o DVT.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's recurrent lobar collapse and respiratory distress can lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
2. Invasive aspergillosis: The patient's treatment with voriconazole and Ambisome for invasive aspergillosis can lead to complications such as liver toxicity and nephrotoxicity.
3. Hypertension: The patient's labile blood pressure can lead to hypertension, which can cause end-organ damage and increase the risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia can increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation can increase the risk of stroke and embolism.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis can increase the risk of infection and sepsis.
7. ESRD on HD: The patient's ESRD on HD can increase the risk of complications such as dialysis disequilibrium syndrome and uremic bleeding.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications. It is essential to closely monitor her condition and adjust her treatment plan accordingly to prevent potential complications and improve her outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old individual admitted to the ICU with a complex medical condition. The patient has been receiving treatment for 24 hours with no periods of hypotension, and their MAPs have remained stable at around 60. They are receiving respiratory support with a BiPap mask and have a SpO2 of 97%. The patient's physical examination is notable for coarse breath sounds, expiratory wheezes, and distant heart sounds. Laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, abnormal electrolyte levels, and impaired renal function. The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk for deep vein thrombosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they require continued respiratory support. The risk of respiratory failure is high, especially with the presence of coarse breath sounds and expiratory wheezes.
2. Cardiac dysrhythmia: The patient's cardiac status is compromised, and they are at risk for cardiac dysrhythmias, especially with the presence of distant heart sounds.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and they are at risk for acute renal failure, which can further complicate their condition.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver function is abnormal, and they are at risk for liver failure, which can lead to further complications.
5. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis, especially with the presence of a PICC line and dialysis catheter.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk for further infections, which can further complicate their condition.
7. Fluid and electrolyte imbalance: The patient's fluid and electrolyte levels are abnormal, and they are at risk for further imbalances, which can lead to further complications.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is receiving nutrition through a feeding tube, but they may be at risk for nutritional deficiencies, especially with the presence of impaired liver function.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   81 yo f with HTN, HL, CHF, ESRD on HD, malnutrition, here with
   recurrent respiratory distress secondary to RLL lobar collapse (?TBM vs
   aspiration with mucous plugging vs HAP) now extubated.
   #.  Respiratory failure:
   Patient has recurrent lobar collapse with respiratory distress.
   Reportedly has TBM but left sided lesion is too distal to stent. Has
   positive glucan/galactomannan, and CT on [**4-14**] showing diffuse disease,
   possibly invasive aspergilliosis. Was started on oral voriconazole on
   [**2190-4-15**], but with elevated LFT
s to thousands; vori was discontinued
   and ambisome was started. Voriconazole was restarted on [**2190-4-24**].
   Completed course for HAP with Vancomycin (D1 [**4-10**]) & cefepime (D1
   [**4-9**]), both d/c
d on [**4-17**]. Due to multiple respiratory problems, patient
   may ultimately require another intubation which she has stated she
   would want.  Will continue to remove fluid as possible with dialysis.
   Must also consider that some component of resp failure could be PE from
   known RUE DVT, though did not tolerate anticoagulation. On periodic
   CPAP Has new MRSA growing in sputum.
   - Vanc dosing at HD protocol
   - Continue voriconazole
   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - consider non-invasive ventilation, CPAP at 8 as needed today
   #.  Thrombocytopenia:
   Platelets have dropped acutely from 118 5 days ago to 55 today. HIT
   neg. Possibly due to Amphoterocin. No drop in HCT to suggest TTP,
   though should check a smear.
   - Add-on smear to morning labs
   - Discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori as LFT
s have improved.
   - cont to monitor
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol on [**4-23**] before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker as needed after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. HTN/Hypotension:
   On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on captopril and amlodipine
   here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **] beta-blocker given concurrent
   rhythm issues.  In ICU has had labile blood pressure. Normotensive this
   AM.
   - will control on metoprolol as needed on non-HD days as per above
   - can restart neo as needed to maintain perfusion
   - maintain a-line for now
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #. Liver:
   Patient had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Though to be shock
   liver due to hypotension following HD. Vori was discontinued, and
   liposomal amphoterocin started. Now that liver enzymes have recovered
   to ALT = 410, AST = 60 have discontinued amphoterocin andrestarted
   voriconazole. Will cont to support pressures to keep SBP above 100.
   Liver ultrasound showed normal right lobe of the liver, limited view of
   the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - cont to trend LFTs now that voriconazole restarted
   # AMS:
   Appears to be related to periods of hypotension.
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Peak WBC had been 28. Is 15 today and has been fluctuating in last 5
   days. Is now back on voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis. Also
   restarted Vancomycin for MRSA positive sputum.
   - follow-up cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of
   anticoagulation.
   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis
   MWF.  Nephrology following.
   - ongoing UF dialysis, plan HD MWF
   - nephrocaps
   - f/u nephrology recs
   - daily weights
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2190-4-26**] 12:28 AM 40 mL/hour

   - f/u ID recs, cultures, fever curve, wbc
   - albuterol/atrovent nebs
   - consider non-invasive ventilation, CPAP at 8 as needed today
   #.  Thrombocytopenia:
   Platelets have dropped acutely from 118 5 days ago to 55 today. HIT
   neg. Possibly due to Amphoterocin. No drop in HCT to suggest TTP,
   though should check a smear.
   - Add-on smear to morning labs
   - Discontinue amphoterocin and restart vori as LFT
s have improved.
   - cont to monitor
   #. NSVT/Afib:
   Patient does have known pafib and appears to have had the episodes of
   NSVT coinciding with dialysis. Given 150mg amio x1 on [**4-12**] and
   continued on drip at 1 then 0.5 per hour. ectopy has improved. now off
   drip and letting patient auto-taper; would try to avoid amio especially
   given her tenuous pulmonary status. Attempted anticoagulation was not
   tolerated by patient due to epistaxis and IV site bleeding.  Did not
   receive metoprolol on [**4-23**] before HD
   - will plan for beta-blocker as needed after HD to control afib
   - cont plan to hold metoprolol 6hrs before HD, hold if SBP<120, hold
   8am dose
   - midodrine 10mg before HD if SBP<120
   - can restart amio and consider longer-term amio if ectopy returns
   #. HTN/Hypotension:
   On nitropaste and amlodipine at home. Was on captopril and amlodipine
   here, however switched to single [**Doctor Last Name **] beta-blocker given concurrent
   rhythm issues.  In ICU has had labile blood pressure. Normotensive this
   AM.
   - will control on metoprolol as needed on non-HD days as per above
   - can restart neo as needed to maintain perfusion
   - maintain a-line for now
   - Manage intravascular volume with HD and UF
   #. Liver:
   Patient had rising LFT
s with peak in the thousands. Though to be shock
   liver due to hypotension following HD. Vori was discontinued, and
   liposomal amphoterocin started. Now that liver enzymes have recovered
   to ALT = 410, AST = 60 have discontinued amphoterocin andrestarted
   voriconazole. Will cont to support pressures to keep SBP above 100.
   Liver ultrasound showed normal right lobe of the liver, limited view of
   the left lobe. No portal vein thrombosis. Echogenic kidneys are
   consistent with parenchymal disease.
   - cont to trend LFTs now that voriconazole restarted
   # AMS:
   Appears to be related to periods of hypotension.
   #.  Leukocytosis:
   Peak WBC had been 28. Is 15 today and has been fluctuating in last 5
   days. Is now back on voriconazole for invasive aspergillosis. Also
   restarted Vancomycin for MRSA positive sputum.
   - follow-up cultures
   - weekly B-glucan, galactomannan
   #. RUE DVT:
    DVT seen on U/S. Patient at risk for PE; however, was intolerant of
   anticoagulation.
   #. ESRD on HD:
   Patient has been on dialysis since recent colectomy.  Gets dialysis
   MWF.  Nephrology following.
   - ongoing UF dialysis, plan HD MWF
   - nephrocaps
   - f/u nephrology recs
   - daily weights
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
